content: The "Boys Town Centennial Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes Boys Town as a nonprofit organization founded in 1917 by Father Flanagan to help children of all races and religions. Father Flanagan's work gained global recognition after the success of the 1938 movie "Boys Town", and he later traveled the world to assist war orphans and advise government leaders on caring for displaced children. Boys Town has expanded to 11 regions across the country, providing care to children and families. The Boys Town National Hotline offers counseling to over 150,000 callers annually. The Boys Town National Research Hospital is a leader in hearing care and Usher Syndrome research. Boys Town programs impact over 2 million children and families each year, with the 100th anniversary of Boys Town approaching on December 12th, 2017. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 Gold Coins as per the Boys Town Centennial Commemorative Coin Act. The Secretary is authorized to mint and issue commemorative coins in honor of the centennial of Father Flanagan's Boys Town. The coins include $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins, each with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act for Boys Town's centennial shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design will symbolize Boys Town's 100 years, with inscriptions of value and the year 2017. The coins minted under this Act for Boys Town's centennial in 2017 will have inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with Boys Town and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens of Coinage Advisory Committee. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017, using only one facility of the United States Mint. The coins minted under this Act for Boys Town's centennial in 2017 will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge of $35 per $5 coin. The Act includes surcharges for different coins: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be paid to Boys Town for their cause. Boys Town will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge can be included if it would exceed the limit for commemorative coins in a calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to ensure that the issuance of commemorative coins does not exceed the annual limit. Financial assurances are required to prevent any net cost to the Federal Government and no funds can be disbursed until all costs are recovered. The United States Treasury recovers expenses for marketing and shipping of commemorative coins, in line with relevant sections of the United States Code.
